Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Experiments with Topological Excitations in Bose-Einstein Condensates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern physics is often an exploration of the extreme environments. For example, the Large Hadron Collider at CERN is a particle accelerator that studies what happens when protons collide at extremely high energy, briefly generating conditions that mimic those of the early universe. At the other end of the energy scale, extremely low-energy collisions (at temperatures only tens of billionths of a degree above absolute zero) contribute to the phenomenon of superfluidity, in which a fluid (such as a very dilute gas) flows without any viscosity. Remarkably, the superfluid gas is itself a pristine "universe," hosting its own "particles" that can be analogues of those existing (or expected to exist) in the cosmos. One example is a particle known as a magnetic monopole, which has not yet been observed but has recently been simulated in a superfluid. Creating such particle-like analogues permits scientists to study some of the properties of anticipated particles in the universe that would otherwise be completely inaccessible, as their creation would exceed the capabilities of even the most powerful particle accelerators. The research in this project is devoted to creation and study of several particle-like structures, including direct analogues of monopoles and more exotic structures known as "knots" and "merons." As simulations, they promise additional insight into the fundamental physical processes of our universe; but they are also of interest in their own right as examples of new and, in many cases, completely unexplored physics. The research program also provides training opportunities for highly motivated undergraduates, a postdoctoral researcher, and a secondary school teacher, with whom we will engage and motivate the next generation of scientists and citizens.


Topological structures are central to diverse branches of physics at many different energy and length scales, including cosmology, particle physics, and condensed-matter physics. Superfluids, such as Bose-Einstein condensates, provide new and exciting opportunities to examine these structures in highly-controlled environments. Notably, the complexity of the order parameter describing the superfluid determines what kind of topological excitations it can support. Here, researchers will examine experimentally several aspects of these topological excitations, including quantized vortex dynamics in scalar condensates (total spin F=0) at nonzero temperature, creation of vortex molecules (or "meron pairs") in pseudospinor condensates (effective spin F=1/2), and linked field configurations in quantum fields (or "knots") in spinor condensates (spin F=1). The excitations will be imprinted by exposing the condensate to time-dependent magnetic and optical fields, and will subsequently be analyzed through examination of atomic density profiles using established imaging techniques. Subsequent studies will study their dynamics and interactions, developing new imaging techniques as required.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project funded by this grant concerned itself with particle-like phenomena that appear in a special material constituted of ultracold atoms. Under the extreme conditions that exist at temperatures only tens of billionths of a degree above absolute zero, the atoms form a phase of matter known as a superfluid, where the material flows without viscosity much as electrons can travel through a superconductor without resistance. Within the superfluid, the particle-like phenomena are not the atoms themselves, but consist of regions where the superfluid is distorted or punctured in a fashion that is persistent and cannot easily disappear, much as (say) a knot in a string cannot be removed if both ends of the string are attached to one another. The knot may be moved around, however, and it is in this sense that the knot can be considered particle-like. The situation in the superfluid is similar to that of the string but in three dimensions, where in addition to knots one can observe phenomena such as skyrmions and monopoles, as well as extended objects such as the miniature tornadoes that are known as vortices. Collectively, these phenomena are known as topological excitations.

 

The project focused on several aspects of topological excitations, including knots, skyrmions, magnetic vortices, two types of monopoles, and an exotic excitation known as an Alice ring. The first challenge the project addressed was to create these excitations in the superfluid; the second, to study how the excitations evolve in time. Although the experiments are all specific to the superfluid, they are closely related to science and mathematics that appear in other contexts, and thus provide an interesting test platform within which to study these common features.

 

In the first experiment, one type of monopole, the isolated monopole, was observed to decay into another type of monopole, the Dirac monopole. This behavior arises because the nonmagnetized superfluid prefers to become magnetized, which changes the type of monopole that can exist. The researchers observed a similar transition between a quantum knot excitation and a kind of magnetic vortex, which also occurred as the superfluid became magnetic.

 

In a second experiment, the researchers discovered that a monopole can also decay into an Alice ring, which is an exotic vortex ring that had not been observed previously. Somewhat paradoxically, the Alice ring has been a subject of interest to high-energy physicists, where it could help to explain why there is more matter than antimatter in the universe. The Alice ring of the superfluid environment is more modest, but it is understood that an isolated monopole passing through the Alice ring will turn into a kind of antimonopole, the equivalent of antimatter in the real world. Thus, future studies of the Alice ring may provide some insight into the more universal physical phenomena.

 

The research team also created a particle-like excitation known as a skyrmion, which is a region in space where the superfluid is knotted into a collection of rings, each linked with every other ring exactly once. Such a configuration closely mimics a theoretical situation in the real world in which magnetic field lines are knotted to form a phenomenon known as ball lightning. See Figure 1.

 

Finally, the research team developed a new technique for creating a magnetic vortex using a trick ascribed to the theoretical physicist Paul A. M. Dirac. In this technique, the team created a magnetic vortex with an effective double winding, which would ordinarily be unstable against decay into a state with no vortex. The researchers played their own trick, however, dividing the initial vortex into two vortices with one winding each. Once separated, neither of the two magnetic vortices could subsequently unwind on its own, and they could be studied individually. Importantly, the team was able to discern a region in "eye" of each vortex where the superfluid transformed itself continuously from its nonmagnetic to its nonmagnetic state. See Figure 2.

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to connecting these results to more universal scientific concepts and ideas, the project provided funding to train two graduate students and several undergraduate students, helping to ensure the high quality of the next generation of researchers in physics. It brought a high school teacher into the lab for a summer, and created a connection in which high school students were able to visit the laboratory, sparking their interest and imagination. Finally, it facilitated an international collaboration involving theorists from England and Finland, and provided critical equipment for continuing studies of these particle-like phenomena.
